issue.title: MAX_THREADS/NUM_THREADS not propagated to Makefile.conf_last
issue.body:
Makefile.install uses MAX_THREADS when writing the pkgconfig file, and falls back to the build host core/thread count when "NUM_THREADS" is not passed to `make install`.

NUM_THREADS is not written to Makefile.conf_last, contrary to e.g. DYNAMIC_ARCH. This is probably an oversight.


There are other options which apparently are not saved when building the library (i.e. everything related to install directories), and are evaluated by `make install`/`Makefile.install`, but there is unfortunately no documentation when each option is evaluated - by `make`, `make install`, or both.

It is probably save to pass all options to both calls, but this is not what the current documentation suggests or uses in the examples.

forkee.name: OpenBLAS
forkee.description: OpenBLAS is an optimized BLAS library based on GotoBLAS2 1.13 BSD version.

issue.title: undefined reference to `__imp__cprintf' linking libopenblas.a on Windows with mingw
issue.body:
In reference to issue: https://github.com/OpenMathLib/OpenBLAS/issues/4263

I am experiencing the same lack of symbol resolution when linking libopenblas.a (0.3.24) using mingw to build a [python package](https://github.com/SugiharaLab/pyEDM) with a c++ extension.  The extension wraps API calls to `dgelss` in a [C++ library](https://github.com/SugiharaLab/cppEDM) (libEDM.a) using pybind11 built on DevOps. 

Following the issue #4263, the pipeline downloads the UCRT build of mingw, however, the unresolved symbols are still present. 

```
g++ -O -Wall -shared -s build\temp.win-amd64-cpython-311\Release\a\1\s\src\bindings\pybind.o build\temp.win-amd64-cpython-311\Release\a\1\s\src\bindings\pyBindEDM.cp311-win_amd64.def -LD:\a\1\s\cppEDM/lib -L/usr/lib/ -LC:\hostedtoolcache\windows\Python\3.11.6\x64\libs -LC:\hostedtoolcache\windows\Python\3.11.6\x64 -LC:\hostedtoolcache\windows\Python\3.11.6\x64\PCbuild\amd64 -lEDM -lopenblas -lgfortran -lpthread -lm -lquadmath -lpython311 -o build\lib.win-amd64-cpython-311\pyBindEDM.cp311-win_amd64.pyd -static -static-libgfortran -static-libgcc
D:/a/1/s/winlib/mingw64/bin/../lib/gcc/x86_64-w64-mingw32/13.2.0/../../../../x86_64-w64-mingw32/bin/ld.exe: D:\a\1\s\cppEDM/lib\libopenblas.a(memory.obj):memory.c:(.text+0x312): undefined reference to `__imp__cprintf'
D:/a/1/s/winlib/mingw64/bin/../lib/gcc/x86_64-w64-mingw32/13.2.0/../../../../x86_64-w64-mingw32/bin/ld.exe: D:\a\1\s\cppEDM/lib\libopenblas.a(memory.obj):memory.c:(.text+0x4f0): undefined reference to `__imp__cprintf'
D:/a/1/s/winlib/mingw64/bin/../lib/gcc/x86_64-w64-mingw32/13.2.0/../../../../x86_64-w64-mingw32/bin/ld.exe: D:\a\1\s\cppEDM/lib\libopenblas.a(xerbla.obj):xerbla.c:(.text+0x13): undefined reference to `__imp__cprintf'
```

This output seems to verify the use of the UCRT build, as I understood this was the resolution to #4263 
```
gcc version 13.2.0 (MinGW-W64 x86_64-ucrt-posix-seh, built by Brecht Sanders) 
```

comment.body:
Possibly, but I'll need to set up a new build environment for that. (MXE was convenient, and I am not much of a Windows person). 
Also I noticed just now that the MXE project wiki has this https://github.com/mxe/mxe/wiki/New-package-troubleshooting suggesting that  unresolved `__imp__something` could be a result of using `declspec(dllimport)` where it is not actually useful

comment.body:
When I use mingw 9.5.0 to build the extension and link against libopenblas.a, the ```undefined reference to `__imp__cprintf'``` seems to be resolved. Thank you.

Unfortunately, the compiled package still fails at python load time, but the posed question seems answered.  

I wonder if a build of libopenblas.a with a new compiler (13) would completely resolve the issue?

issue.title: VisualStudio's findBLAS.cmake fails to locate a precompiled libopenblas when building SuiteSparse
issue.body:
Hi all

I've been struggling with the combination Windows/OpenBLAS/Suitesparse/MS VisualStudio/CMake for several month already, so I finally decided to ask for help.

1) I build Suitesparse under Windowsx64 with MSVS. I download precompiled OpenBLASx64 binaries to a local directory and want to link Suitespase to it.

2) Suitesparse's CMakeLists.txt calls SuiteSparseBLAS.cmake, which it its turn calls `find_package(BLAS)`. It translates to a call to findBLAS.cmake (shipped with MSVS).

3) findBLAS.cmake fails to locate OpenBLAS (actually, it can be verified directly, without Suitesparse)

4) I experimented a lot with different options (BLA_VENDOR/ALLOW_64BIT_BLAS etc) and debugged findBLAS.cmake. So I am pretty confident that something wrong with the findBLAS.cmake logic. For example, findBLAS.cmake expects "64" in lib names, whereas the precompiled binaries are named simply "libopenblas". However, I suspect that there are more serious problems in the logic.

5)The only solution I found is to edit Suitesparse's cmake files, remove `find_package(BLAS)` call,and set everything manually:
```
set(BLAS_FOUND ON);
set(BLAS_LABRARIES ..);
..
```
Which is ugly of course.

6) Note that the "Config.cmake" files shipped with OpenBLAS are of little help, because `find_package()` looks for findXXX.cmake files first - and the file is there.

7) **The question: how to force findBLAS.cmake to locate precompiled OpenBLAS libraries, privided that `find_package(BLAS)` is called somewhere inside another library?**

comment.body: I just noticed OpenCV changed their own version of  FindBLAS.cmake to add "libopenblas" as a name variant to look for. On the other hand, having the Windows libraries named with the Unix-style "lib" prefix appears to have been a (mis?)feature even in the original GotoBLAS2, and as far as I can tell, distributors like MSYS2 do not appear to patch that out(?)

issue.title: undefined reference to `__imp__cprintf' linking libopenblas.a on Windows with mingw
issue.body:
In reference to issue: https://github.com/OpenMathLib/OpenBLAS/issues/4263

I am experiencing the same lack of symbol resolution when linking libopenblas.a (0.3.24) using mingw to build a [python package](https://github.com/SugiharaLab/pyEDM) with a c++ extension.  The extension wraps API calls to `dgelss` in a [C++ library](https://github.com/SugiharaLab/cppEDM) (libEDM.a) using pybind11 built on DevOps. 

Following the issue #4263, the pipeline downloads the UCRT build of mingw, however, the unresolved symbols are still present. 


comment.body: Prebuilt is cross-compiled on Linux using the "MXE" environment for mingw, which uses the old 9.3.0 - maybe this creates an incompatibility with your mingw 12/13 build. The `__imp__cprintf` appears to be mingw's translation of a print to stderr

comment.body:
This uses prebuilt binary libopenblas.a from https://sourceforge.net/projects/openblas/. 

As I don't have a Windows build environment, I did not build openblas from source. 

Builds are done on a DevOps pipeline, so each build should be "clean". The lack of resolution is the same whether using the default mingw 12.2.0 (I presume MSVRCT), or the UCRT mingw versions 12.2.0 and 13.2.0.

comment.body: Unfortunately I do not think we got a clear resolution for #4263 - so far this looks as if it was an installation problem of mingw, perhaps caused by having multiple versions of mingw installed. Both MSVCRT or UCRT version were found to work when installed on a "clean" system. Did you compile OpenBLAS yourself (and if so, did you see the same kind of errors there), or did you use the binary release package (which is compiled with a different, older version of mingw) ?

issue.title: VisualStudio's findBLAS.cmake fails to locate a precompiled libopenblas when building SuiteSparse
issue.body:
Hi all

I've been struggling with the combination Windows/OpenBLAS/Suitesparse/MS VisualStudio/CMake for several month already, so I finally decided to ask for help.

1) I build Suitesparse under Windowsx64 with MSVS. I download precompiled OpenBLASx64 binaries to a local directory and want to link Suitespase to it.

2) Suitesparse's CMakeLists.txt calls SuiteSparseBLAS.cmake, which it its turn calls `find_package(BLAS)`. It translates to a call to findBLAS.cmake (shipped with MSVS).

3) findBLAS.cmake fails to locate OpenBLAS (actually, it can be verified directly, without Suitesparse)

4) I experimented a lot with different options (BLA_VENDOR/ALLOW_64BIT_BLAS etc) and debugged findBLAS.cmake. So I am pretty confident that something wrong with the findBLAS.cmake logic. For example, findBLAS.cmake expects "64" in lib names, whereas the precompiled binaries are named simply "libopenblas". However, I suspect that there are more serious problems in the logic.

5)The only solution I found is to edit Suitesparse's cmake files, remove `find_package(BLAS)` call,and set everything manually:
```
set(BLAS_FOUND ON);
set(BLAS_LABRARIES ..);
..
```
Which is ugly of course.

6) Note that the "Config.cmake" files shipped with OpenBLAS are of little help, because `find_package()` looks for findXXX.cmake files first - and the file is there.

7) **The question: how to force findBLAS.cmake to locate precompiled OpenBLAS libraries, privided that `find_package(BLAS)` is called somewhere inside another library?**

comment.body: so the main problem on OpenBLAS' side is the unwanted Linux-like "lib" prefix on the library files ?  Not sure if we've alwayss had it (and nobody bothered to complain) or if it crept in during some rearrangement of the build files,  but if its only purpose is to cause trouble I'll remove it for future versions

3) findBLAS.cmake fails to locate OpenBLAS (actually, it can be verified directly, without Suitesparse)

4) I experimented a lot with different options (BLA_VENDOR/ALLOW_64BIT_BLAS etc) and debugged findBLAS.cmake. So I am pretty confident that something wrong with the findBLAS.cmake logic. For example, findBLAS.cmake expects "64" in lib names, whereas the precompiled binaries are named simply "libopenblas". However, I suspect that there are more serious problems in the logic.

5)The only solution I found is to edit Suitesparse's cmake files, remove `find_package(BLAS)` call,and set everything manually:
```

set(BLAS_LABRARIES ..);
..
```
Which is ugly of course.

6) Note that the "Config.cmake" files shipped with OpenBLAS are of little help, because `find_package()` looks for findXXX.cmake files first - and the file is there.

7) **The question: how to force findBLAS.cmake to locate precompiled OpenBLAS libraries, privided that `find_package(BLAS)` is called somewhere inside another library?**

comment.body:
@martin-frbg 

You were right in that it boiles down to where `find_library` search for the libraries. After one another investigation I found the following solution.

1. Set BLA_VENDOR="OpenBLAS"  ALLOW_64BIT_BLAS="OFF" (it is also possible to set ALLOW_64BIT_BLAS="ON" **AND** ask @martin-frbg to compile openblas64.lib)
2. Specify additional CMake search directory by setting CMAKE_LIBRARY_PATH="C: ../OpenBLAS-0.3.24-x64/lib"  (path to the *.lib)
3. Rename precompiled binary by removing leading "lib" from file names ( "libopenblas.lib" ->"openblas.lib" )

If someone wants to debug it in the future, I extracted a piece of code from findBLAS.cmake that actually performs the search when find_package(BLAS) with BLA_VENDOR="OpenBLAS" is called.

```
        find_library(BLAS_openblas_LIBRARY #  or BLAS_openblas64_LIBRARY
          NAMES openblas  #<---  or "openblas64"
          ""
          PATHS "LIB;ENV"
          PATH_SUFFIXES ""
        )
```

Normally after the call it should be BLAS_openblas_LIBRARY="C:/.../openblas.lib"

PS I use Microsoft Visual Studio Community 2022 (64-bit) - Current Version 17.6.5

issue.title: Error handling is poor
issue.body:
Error handling in OpenBLAS is currently poor and inconsistent. Some routines, such as `gemm_driver`, call `exit` when memory cannot be allocated; that's a no-no for library code. Other routines are even worse: they fail to check whether memory has been allocated and just continue, causing segfaults. Error messages may be printed, but sometimes to go to `stdout`, sometimes to `stderr`.

Apple's BLAS has a `SetBLASParamErrorProc` function that allows installing a custom error handler. Implementing this API in OpenBLAS might be a good idea.

comment.body: hmm, that hardware looks normal enough (though I'm not sure if I have something similar enough to reproduce the problem). Does it happen with a reasonably recent OpenBLAS, and with some publicly available source ?

The full test report can be found [in this gist](https://gist.github.com/casparvl/123448abe53a3698472212a62c8a341f).

Now, admittedly, I don't have much experience in interpreting the results of the Lapack test suite.

issue.title: VisualStudio's findBLAS.cmake fails to locate a precompiled libopenblas when building SuiteSparse
issue.body:
Hi all

I've been struggling with the combination Windows/OpenBLAS/Suitesparse/MS VisualStudio/CMake for several month already, so I finally decided to ask for help.

1) I build Suitesparse under Windowsx64 with MSVS. I download precompiled OpenBLASx64 binaries to a local directory and want to link Suitespase to it.

2) Suitesparse's CMakeLists.txt calls SuiteSparseBLAS.cmake, which it its turn calls `find_package(BLAS)`. It translates to a call to findBLAS.cmake (shipped with MSVS).

3) findBLAS.cmake fails to locate OpenBLAS (actually, it can be verified directly, without Suitesparse)

4) I experimented a lot with different options (BLA_VENDOR/ALLOW_64BIT_BLAS etc) and debugged findBLAS.cmake. So I am pretty confident that something wrong with the findBLAS.cmake logic. For example, findBLAS.cmake expects "64" in lib names, whereas the precompiled binaries are named simply "libopenblas". However, I suspect that there are more serious problems in the logic.

5)The only solution I found is to edit Suitesparse's cmake files, remove `find_package(BLAS)` call,and set everything manually:
```
set(BLAS_FOUND ON);
set(BLAS_LABRARIES ..);
..
```
Which is ugly of course.

6) Note that the "Config.cmake" files shipped with OpenBLAS are of little help, because `find_package()` looks for findXXX.cmake files first - and the file is there.

7) **The question: how to force findBLAS.cmake to locate precompiled OpenBLAS libraries, privided that `find_package(BLAS)` is called somewhere inside another library?**

comment.body: So this probably reduces to where did you install (unpack) the zip of OpenBLAS, and which locations does FindBLAS.cmake check - and problems finding BLAS appear to be quite a popular question on the Usage forum at discourse.cmake.org. Incidentally, which version of VisualStudio (one thread there suggested using at least VS 2017 15.0 to have detection work), and have you tried running the cmake build with `--debug-find` ?

comment.body:
> No, x32/x64 is a different thing altogether - this is not about 32bit platform, but about using a larger than usual type for integral numbers - "long long" instead of "long" in MSVC syntax. I wonder where the "openblas64" in _blas_openblas_lib comes from - from the SuiteSparse docs I would expect it to search for this variant only when ALLOW_64BIT_BLAS is set in Suitesparse_config

Ok, now I see. I use ALLOW_64BIT_BLAS=ON, and then it translates into BLA_SIZEOF_INTEGER=8 somewhere inside Suitesparse cmake files. If I change ALLOW_64BIT_BLAS=OFF, then BLA_SIZEOF_INTEGER=4, then findBLAS.cmake searches for "openblas", and then fails anyway.

So the problem persists.

comment.body:
No, x32/x64 is a different thing altogether - this is not about 32bit platform, but about using a larger than usual type for integral numbers - "long long" instead of "long" in MSVC syntax.
I wonder where  the "openblas64" in _blas_openblas_lib comes from - from the SuiteSparse docs I would expect it to search for this variant only when ALLOW_64BIT_BLAS is set in Suitesparse_config

issue.body:

I've been struggling with the combination Windows/OpenBLAS/Suitesparse/MS VisualStudio/CMake for several month already, so I finally decided to ask for help.

3) findBLAS.cmake fails to locate OpenBLAS (actually, it can be verified directly, without Suitesparse)

4) I experimented a lot with different options (BLA_VENDOR/ALLOW_64BIT_BLAS etc) and debugged findBLAS.cmake. So I am pretty confident that something wrong with the findBLAS.cmake logic. For example, findBLAS.cmake expects "64" in lib names, whereas the precompiled binaries are named simply "libopenblas". However, I suspect that there are more serious problems in the logic.

5)The only solution I found is to edit Suitesparse's cmake files, remove `find_package(BLAS)` call,and set everything manually:
```

set(BLAS_LABRARIES ..);
..
```
Which is ugly of course.

6) Note that the "Config.cmake" files shipped with OpenBLAS are of little help, because `find_package()` looks for findXXX.cmake files first - and the file is there.

7) **The question: how to force findBLAS.cmake to locate precompiled OpenBLAS libraries, privided that `find_package(BLAS)` is called somewhere inside another library?**

comment.body:
@martin-frbg Thank you for your quick reply

You say "the provided binaries are x32", but I downloaded archive named "OpenBLAS-0.3.24-x64.zip" - it seems to be x64, right?

I think that the main problem with findBLAS.cmake is a this call below. It actually performs the OpenBLAS search:

```
    check_blas_libraries(
      BLAS_LIBRARIES
      BLAS
      sgemm
      ""
      "${_blas_openblas_lib}"  //<---  this guy here is "openblas64"
      ""
      ""
      ""
      )
```

So you see, that all directories provided for `check_blas_libraries()` are empty. I looked inside `check_blas_libraries()` under debugger and discovered that the actual job is done with the call
```
        find_library(${_prefix}_${_lib_var}_LIBRARY  //<-- "BLAS_openblas64_LIBRARY"
          NAMES ${_library}  //<--- "openblas64"
          NAMES_PER_DIR  //<-- empty
          PATHS ${_extaddlibdir} //<--- "ENV;LIB"
          PATH_SUFFIXES ${_subdirs} //<--- empty
        )
```

No local directories are given to `find_library` function, apart from "ENV" and "LIB". After this call BLAS_openblas64_LIBRARY has value "BLAS_openblas64_LIBRARY-NOTFOUND".

4) I experimented a lot with different options (BLA_VENDOR/ALLOW_64BIT_BLAS etc) and debugged findBLAS.cmake. So I am pretty confident that something wrong with the findBLAS.cmake logic. comment.body:
If the findBLAS.cmake really looks specifically for a libopenblas64, it probably expects a library built with the INTERFACE64=1 option to declare all integers as 64bit long rather than the standard 32bits to extend the range of numbers (addressable array elements) The provided binaries are built with standard 32bit integers only, I can see if I can find the time to build another package with INTERFACE64 for you. 
However it appears to me that using a "64bit" BLAS in SuiteSparse is still entirely optional and depends on the settings made in/with SuiteSparse_config - the ALLOW_64BIT_BLAS option you saw.
